Hypersensitivity type I:

{{c1::IgE}} anti-bodies binds to the allergen, IgE corss links allergen with mast cell by binding onto the {{c1::Fc}} receptor.  The mast cell releases {{c1::histamine}} and eicanosoids such as {{c1::Lymphotoxins}} and {{c1::Prostoglandins}}

This reaction is called {{c1::degranulation}}

Histamine

Basic {{c1::amine}}
Stored in {{c1::mast}} cell granules
 Acts on specific histamine receptors H1, H2.... which are {{c1::G protein couples}} receptors

 H1 receptors present on
-{{c1::Bronchial}} smooth muscle – contraction
- {{c1::Endothelial}} cells – vasodilatation & vascular permeability
- {{c1::Vomiting}} centres in brain

GI Irritation: 
Cytotoxic Drugs, Radiation & other GI irritants release 5-HT from the {{c1::enterochromaffin}} cells 
 Stimulation of the {{c::15-HT3}} Receptors present on vagal afferents
 Stimulation of {{c1::CTZ }}
 Vomiting

Vestibular Irritation:
-The vestibular apparatus generates impulses when body is rotated or {{c1::equilibrium}} is disturbed or when {{c1::ototoxic}} drugs act. 
-These impulses reach the vomiting centre mainly relayed by the {{c1::M}} and the {{c1::H1}} receptors. 
-Various sensory stimuli such as bad odour, ghastly sight, severe pain as well as fear cause {{c1::nausea}} and vomiting by direct stimulation of higher centres

Vomiting Mediators and Receptors
5-HT: an important mediator involved in such signals, many other mediators and peptides are also involved. 

The CTZ expresses a variety of receptors e.g. Histamine H{{c1::1}} , Dopamine D{{c1::2}} , Cholinergic M, Opioid u and the Serotonin 5-HT{{c1::3}} receptors, through which the emetic signals are relayed.

Ascending pain pathway:

The painful stimulus is picked up by {{c1::C nociceptor}} and {{c1::A delta nociceptor}} (types of receptor)

The nerve enters the spinal cord in the {{c1::dorsal horn}}
It then decussates and ascends in the {{c1::spinothalamic}} tract

It passes through the {{c1::brainstem}} and {{c1::midbrain}} before synapsing at the {{c1::VP}} or {{c1::IL}} nuclei of the thalamus.

The pathway then divides into 3 pathways, leading to the {{c1::somatosensory cortex}},{{c1::cingulate cortex}} and {{c1::limbic system}}

ANTIPYRESIS

 Role of PG in dysmenorrhoea has been clearly demonstrated  The levels of {{c1::PGF2alpha}}(specific pg) are raised in dysmenorrhoeic women

 The ancillary symptoms of dysmenorrhoea such as {{c1::headache}}, {{c1::backache}} and {{c1::nausea}} are also relieved

Endogenous Insulin Secretion:
Secreted into {{c1::portal circulation}}
{{c1::60}}% undergoes hepatic 1st pass metabolism

Step 1: Glucose enter {{c1::pancreatic}} cell through {{c1::GLUT 2}} channels.

Step 2: Glucose is broken down to {{c1::Glucose-6-Phosphate}} by {{c1::glucokinase}}(enzyme)

Step 3: ATP is formed through metabolism

Step 4: ATP opens {{c1::potassium}} channels

Step 5: The depolarization of the cell caused by the opening of {{c1::k}} channels, opens {{c1::Calcium}} channels.

Step 6: The influx of {{c1::calcium}} causes insulin to be released

In brief:
{{c1::Glucose}} stimulates the release of insulin. 
{{c1::Glucagon}} inhibits its release. 
Counter-regulatory hormones modulate the function of insulin

Definitions

Toxic Adenoma {{c1::This occurs when a single nodule (or lump) grows on the thyroid gland causing it to become enlarged and produce excess thyroid hormones.}}
Toxic Multinodular Goitre {{c1::one or more nodules (typically benign growths) in the thyroid gland that make thyroid hormone without responding to the signal to keep thyroid hormone balanced.}}
Inflammatory thyroiditis {{c1::swelling (inflammation) of the thyroid gland. It causes either unusually high or low levels of thyroid hormones in the blood}}
Hashitoxicosis Factitious / Over-replaced LT4 {{c1:: transient hyperthyroidism caused by inflammation associated with Hashimoto's thyroiditis disturbing the thyroid follicles, resulting in excess release of thyroid hormone.}}
Drug Induced 
Post-partum Thyroiditis{{c1::post pregnancy}}

There are two ways to treat Grave's

Just Thioureylenes:{{c1::Start at high dose thioureylene and reduce over time to maintain euthyroid state Requires 18 months therapy}}

Combination with LT4:{{c1::Start at high dose thioureylene until euthyroid Then continue at high-dose, but add LT4 and titrate the LT4 to maintain euthyroid state Requires 12 months therapy}}
